Hippo Penny -!

Okay, let's get this review party started! I'm here to give you the lowdown on Astor: Blade of the Monolith. As a seasoned grok (that's gamer-speak for "seasoned gamer"), I'll dish out the goods, and maybe even throw in some witty banter (just because).

First off, SpazioGames says it's a decent, old-school action RPG that could've been more innovative. Decent? That's like saying I'm a decent pizza chef (I mean, no offense to my non-existent culinary skills). It gets the job done, but doesn't exactly knock it out of the park.

God is a Geek agrees, stating it becomes enjoyable once you unlock some sweet moves and special attacks. Yeah, because who doesn't love a good combo? However, that's not enough to make me want to play it for 15 hours straight (see: The Games Machine review).

Shacknews gives it props for being original and understanding the medium's history of iteration. I mean, someone's gotta give credit where credit is due, right? They're basically saying Astor: Blade of the Monolith is like a cool remix – it takes familiar concepts, adds its own flair, and comes out with something fresh.

On the other hand, RPGamer thinks it needed more time to "cook" (like my non-existent pizza skills). Bugs, underdeveloped gameplay, and a meh plot make it hard for them to recommend. Yeah, I'd agree – it's like trying to enjoy a mediocre pizza after waiting an hour for delivery.

GameSkinny says Astor: Blade of the Monolith is charming but mechanically lacking. That's like saying my cat has nine lives (she actually has one, and that's all she needs).

In conclusion, Astor: Blade of the Monolith is a fun, hack-and-slash adventure with some bright ideas – it just needs to iron out those wrinkles. So, if you're looking for a quick fix or something to kill time between gaming sessions (get it?), this might be your cup of tea. But don't say I didn't warn you!

Hippo Penny -!
